name: Blue Jay
paragraphs: Blue jays are native to North America and known for their vibrant blue plumage.
They are intelligent and vocal birds, often imitating the calls of hawks.
Blue jays inhabit forests, parks, and suburban areas where they forage for nuts and seeds.

name: Owl
paragraphs: Owls are nocturnal raptors with exceptional hearing and silent flight.
They inhabit diverse habitats from forests to deserts worldwide.
Owls primarily hunt small mammals and insects, using keen vision in low light.

name: Parrot
paragraphs: Parrots are social birds known for their bright colors and vocal learning.
Many species inhabit tropical and subtropical regions.
They have strong curved beaks suited for cracking nuts and seeds.

name: Eagle
paragraphs: Eagles are large birds of prey with powerful talons and keen eyesight.
They often nest in tall trees or cliffs near water bodies.
Diet includes fish, small mammals, and carrion depending on species.

name: Crow
paragraphs: Crows are highly intelligent corvids known for tool use and problem solving.
They thrive in urban and rural environments globally.
Omnivorous diet includes insects, seeds, and human refuse.

name: Hummingbird
paragraphs: Hummingbirds are tiny birds capable of hovering with rapid wingbeats.
They feed on nectar and small insects, aiding pollination.
Found mainly in the Americas with dazzling iridescent plumage.

name: Penguin
paragraphs: Penguins are flightless seabirds adapted for swimming in cold oceans.
They breed in colonies, often on subantarctic and Antarctic islands.
Diet consists mainly of fish, krill, and squid.

name: Flamingo
paragraphs: Flamingos are wading birds noted for their pink plumage from carotenoid-rich diets.
They inhabit saline lakes, lagoons, and estuaries.
They feed by filter-feeding with uniquely adapted bills.

name: Peacock
paragraphs: Peacocks are male peafowl famous for their iridescent tail displays.
Native to South Asia, they inhabit forests and farmlands.
Displays serve to attract mates and deter rivals.

name: Robin
paragraphs: Robins are widespread thrushes known for orange breasts and melodic song.
Common in gardens and woodlands across North America and Europe.
They forage for worms, insects, and fruit.

name: Lion
paragraphs: Lions are social big cats living in prides on African savannas.
Males bear manes; females are primary hunters.
Prey includes antelope, zebra, and buffalo.

name: Tiger
paragraphs: Tigers are solitary apex predators of Asian forests and grasslands.
Distinctive orange coats with black stripes provide camouflage.
They hunt deer, boar, and other large mammals.

name: Elephant
paragraphs: Elephants are the largest land mammals, highly social and intelligent.
They inhabit savannas, forests, and deserts in Africa and Asia.
Diet mainly consists of grasses, leaves, and bark.

name: Wolf
paragraphs: Wolves are pack-living canids known for cooperative hunting and howling.
They inhabit forests, tundra, and mountains of the Northern Hemisphere.
Diet centers on ungulates like deer and elk.

name: Bear
paragraphs: Bears are large omnivores with varied diets and seasonal behaviors.
They occupy forests, tundra, and mountains worldwide.
Hibernation helps some species survive winter scarcity.

name: Kangaroo
paragraphs: Kangaroos are iconic Australian marsupials with powerful hind legs.
They inhabit open grasslands and woodlands.
Herbivorous grazers feeding on grasses and shrubs.

name: Dolphin
paragraphs: Dolphins are intelligent marine mammals using echolocation to navigate.
They form complex social groups and display playful behavior.
Diet consists of fish and squid, caught cooperatively.

name: Bat
paragraphs: Bats are the only flying mammals, active mostly at night.
They pollinate plants, disperse seeds, and control insect populations.
Many species use echolocation to hunt in darkness.

name: Zebra
paragraphs: Zebras are African equids recognized by black-and-white stripes.
They live in herds on savannas and grasslands.
Stripes may disrupt predator vision or help with thermoregulation.

name: Giraffe
paragraphs: Giraffes are the tallest living terrestrial animals.
They browse tree canopies with long tongues and necks.
Social groups are fluid and often change composition.

name: Crocodile
paragraphs: Crocodiles are large aquatic reptiles with powerful jaws.
They inhabit tropical rivers, lakes, and wetlands.
Ambush predators feeding on fish, birds, and mammals.

name: Snake
paragraphs: Snakes are limbless reptiles with highly flexible jaws.
They occupy diverse habitats from deserts to forests.
Diet varies widely, including rodents, birds, and amphibians.

name: Lizard
paragraphs: Lizards are a diverse group with over 7,000 species.
They range from tiny geckos to large monitor lizards.
Primarily insectivorous, some are herbivores or omnivores.

name: Turtle
paragraphs: Turtles are reptiles with bony shells for protection.
They live in oceans, freshwater, and on land as tortoises.
Many species migrate long distances to nest.

name: Chameleon
paragraphs: Chameleons change color for communication and thermoregulation.
They have independently moving eyes and projectile tongues.
Most inhabit forests and scrub in Africa and Madagascar.

name: Frog
paragraphs: Frogs are amphibians with permeable skin and jumping legs.
They breed in water and undergo metamorphosis from tadpoles.
Calls are used to attract mates and defend territories.

name: Salamander
paragraphs: Salamanders are tailed amphibians often found in moist habitats.
Many have regenerative abilities for limbs and tails.
Diet includes insects, worms, and small invertebrates.

name: Newt
paragraphs: Newts are semi-aquatic salamanders with smooth skin.
They split time between water and land across the year.
Reproduction typically involves aquatic eggs and larvae.

name: Butterfly
paragraphs: Butterflies are insects with scaled wings and complete metamorphosis.
They pollinate flowers and serve as ecological indicators.
Monarchs migrate thousands of kilometers annually.

name: Bee
paragraphs: Bees are vital pollinators with complex social behaviors in many species.
They collect nectar and pollen to feed colonies.
Threats include habitat loss, pesticides, and disease.

name: Ladybug
paragraphs: Ladybugs are beneficial beetles that eat aphids and scale insects.
Bright colors warn predators of distasteful chemicals.
Found in gardens, fields, and forests worldwide.
